comments.commentBody: I'm a flight instructor and can confirm that cell phones on the frequency band used by AT&T and T-mobile will interfere with the airplane's audio,  They create an occasional buzzing sound. Verizon and Sprint don't. Former students of mine who are now airline pilots confirm the same interference on the pilot's intercom and communications equipment of regional jets. I've never observed any interference on navigation equipment. Obviously a cell phone incorporates a transmitter. On the other hand, I've never seen any interference from other devices, such as laptops, cameras, camcorders, etc. I don't know about other carriers' phones, but Sprint phones won't work any higher than about 1500 feet above ground when they try to connect with multiple towers.

Thanx, Fact Boy, for that explication of what happens in H&G.   I need to get on those Fairy Tales that I was looking forward to reading once.  The originals, of course.  23A Spider-man serves as a sort of modern day fairy tale or myth, I guess.  The GREENGOBLIN was co-created by Steve Ditko who did his own version of fractured fairy tales in the early 1950s horror comic books, Rumpelstiltsken being the most memorable.   The GG is not the first supervillain SM encountered; it's the Chameleon.  18D  CHER seems oddly like a half-name rather than  a regular full name.  It'd throw me off.  I liked her in the Beavis & Butthead video version of "I Got You, Babe".  10D, 41D, and 35D  Love the inclusion of these two archaeologically related terms.  17A  Still have this stuff around? IC, this TUENYTXWP had a jerky feel to it, which means it was definitely worth my while.

Nearly got stuck in the lower right. Had no idea on 44a, wasn't seeing LABYRINTH, and similarly had no clue for 57d (meta? really?). Finally ran through the alphabet for 65a and saw it, which gave me the rest.

Good Tuesday puzzle. You go girl - looking forward to more.

Fact boy. Small sample size there for that conclusion.

I think I'll skip the vid today, Deb. Not quite up for that.

Yep, I have the same complaints... adobe is a material, not a building; the bread crumbs were "intended" route markers; "pants part" is a crummy clue for HEM; panda "bear" is no longer used (I think, but why didn't Fact Boy complain?). But in my book, anyone who can construct a puzzle is to be admired, so good job Aimee. Glad you've joined the Onion Set. (hehe)

That video of the Cher impersonator...I can't watch videos on dial-up, so I just look at the still photo. Looks like Cher is wearing an athletic cup. And has a tail. Weird.
in california the buildings are called adobes. there's vallejo's adobe, for instance, in petaluma. in 1850's san francisco there was a public building called the old adobe.

Catching up for the past ten days, I want first to express my condolences to Martin. I loved that IRS story!

And a (belated) Happy Birthday to Suejean! BTW, your saying I was on holiday early last week (instead of on vacation) made me understand after all these years why the Gregory Peck- Audrey Hepburn movie was titled Roman Holiday and I thank you for clearing up that mystery for me.

The rest of the days are a blur as I was enjoying my clan too much, until the Yin Yang on Sunday where sbmanion @ 28 said exactly what I was thinking after I did the puzzle. Never heard anyone in Chicago refer to Sammy Sosa as slammin’, especially after the steroids and corked bats. And I enjoyed the comment by Jeff Chen maybe even more than his puzzle. He is very funny and, like me, blames Deb for everything wrong, regardless.

And I thought Monday’s was one of Acme’s better puzzles, even producing her own Monday Yin Yang with beautiful boys vs. beige babes.

Finally, Tuesday’s puzzle is on the money….

I'm always happy to see a female byline, and doubly happy when the puzzle is quite good.  The clues felt fresh and young, and I wondered if this came from a Brown student/recent alum.  Thanks for a fun solve.

As a supporter of Occupy Wall Street, I am profoundly saddened to learn that a clear antisemite has inspired its formation.  The Occupy movement must disavow and transcend Kalle Lasn if it is to continue to be a voice of hope to the world .

Let us at least look at the fictive language of the proposed settlement in which a wild and crazy scheme that effected a fraud on investors (as alleged) is also considered to be a result of negligence.  This is a crazy quirk in the judicial gloss on the Securities Act of 1933.  Either something is a fraud or it is a non-fraudulent disclosure violation.  It cannot be a negligent fraud -- no matter the parsings of a Supreme Court 35 odd years ago.  Judge Rakoff suspects that SEC civil (it has NO criminal jurisdiction)settlements may be mere paper shuffles.  Very well, but private attorneys, even if they could not win on issue preclusion could get a huge boost from the SEC's files AND the $285 million does go part way to ensuring a plaintiff's pot to distribute.  And, who are the individual defendants, if any?  Are they living up in Greenwich or in the Beresford.  How much will the SEC get from them?  How many lives do they get to live.  They are not cats.

I get that this metric shows where the establishment is versus the electorate but it is limiting even given that:

For one, endorsers rarely change their minds because it makes them look wobbly. But how many Perry endorsers would make the same decision today? This cumulative look distorts current opinion.

Also, establishment figures largely play it safe since they have careers and favors on the line. Their decision often has little to do with ideology or candidate quality which are primary factors for most voters.

Finally, you acknowledge that endorsements have different weight but there are only a handful that really matter. Those are the opinion leaders who endorse not for career reasons but for principle or to build a movement. Palin, Demint, Rubio, Ryan fit this profile. Even supposedly influential figures like Christie and (in their respective states) Branstad, Haley, and Scott aren't as important because they are clearly calculating how the endorsement will help their personal political situations. So tallying up all these insignificant endorsements may be like an establishment opinion poll but we should not bother asking whether the elite drives popular opinion or not because we already know that this portion of the elite does not.

When Palin and Demint endorse (Rubio and Ryan won't) you will see how opinion leaders move opinion. Just don't conflate the overall establishment elite with the opinion leader subset.

Perhaps good old fashioned politics can accomplish the change that is needed. Judging by the Republicans' insistance on no taxes - that may be doubtful. Here's a part of the list: A wealth tax. Restoration of Eisenhower or pre-Eisenhower tax rates on higher incomes. Restoration of the Estate Tax (the Republicans like to call it the "Death Tax", I prefer to think of it as the "Death to Feudalism Tax") Restoration of Glass-Steagel (pls excuse spelling). An end to the fiction of corporate personhood (I saw this great sign at an Occupy rally - kudos to the genius who came up with it: Slavery is the fiction that People are Property. Corporate Personhood is the fiction that Property is People.)

I believe that most Americans now understand that the inequality of wealth and power that has been allowed to develop is incompatible with Democracy. It is up to those that have one these game to cede to the American people their economic and political sovereignty. Or the routine business of politics necessary to restore our democracy may have to pursue politics by other means.

The only way to fix American politics is to split into two separate countries for Democrats and Republicans!

I would have a lot more respect for all the "educated," white liberals if they'd be a little more honest with themselves and with me about their true motives.  They are like drug dealers and the poor black and Hispanics are the addicts.  Instead of exchanging drugs for money, however, they exchange power for entitlements.  The people who get addicted to the entitlements lose their initiative, self-reliance and self-respect.  The "educated," white  liberals who give the handouts get a twofer.  They get to control others by doling out money and, at the same time, they get to feel smug about what intelligent, superior, compassionate people they are.  Remember the old saying:  If you give a person a fish, he can eat for one day, but if you teach a person to fish, he can feed himself for the rest of his life.  "Educated" white liberals don't want the poor to learn to fish.  If they did, the poor wouldn't have to do what they are told.  By the way, I put "educated" in quotation marks because the highly educated  are not necessarily smart, logical or wise.  They just think they are.

Obama could not have gotten elected in 08 without the white vote. For many of the whites who voted for him, casting their ballots was a fashion statement; "Look how open-minded I am, voting for this underqualified black man just to show how unprejudiced I am." Many of those voters have since taken an economic shellacking. Obama can only appeal to two classes of voters- those who are economically ignorant, and those who are economically above the fray. This is another way of saying those two classes who do not work for a living.

Unbelievable. This reads like a department-store strategy for advertising women's clothing fashions. Or perhaps a nerd/dork concept for never again having to face jocks in high-school hallways. These "strategists" are prepared to dismember and discard the living body politic of the Democratric party. The only thing that might prevent the results of this from being as bad as they should be is the grotesque quality of 2012's Republican primary contestants.

Begging for common sense feels futile here, doesn't it? Nonetheless, how about this: Dump the fraud, failure, and Wall Street front man Obama (yes, I voted for him). Nominate a true and trustworthy Democrat - they can be found - draft Bernie Sanders! Then kick the moneychangers out of the Democratic temples of DC, and fight without equivocation with truth and justice. Make sure to include a powerful website that addresses every issue before government, explains and discusses each honestly, and commits to a forceful and detailed Democratic answers for every one. Simple truths demanded and begged for - we want them, but we're not getting them. Have we ever? Provide them and win - without the neurotic derangement of insulting the white working class out the door.

Uneducated IS the reason that so many middle class whites vote against their own best interest. If the average American took the time to read up on what is actually happening to our country they would then understand that they are being pushed off the cliff by the very people they vote for---The Republican Party. Republicans are bought and paid for as a whole---democrats are bought and paid for as a bunch, but not all. Until we have a third party--and we will soon, we can only do the prudent thing and vote against the party that will most certainly continue to destroy middle class America---the Republican Party.

Mr. Pinker and so many like him (Wilson, et. al) are too focused on the ape side of human for explanations of our 'nature' and hence, behaviors.  No doubt there's a there there, but largely ignoring the unimaginable power of our symbolic mind, drenched with imagination and emotion is missing much more than half the picture.  Hard to cotton to ideas of someone who views art as pleasurable diversion on the order of ice cream or cake....

My family fled the Vietnam war as refugees, and decades before that they fled China due to the civil war there. In only 2 generations we have known extreme violence, and extreme peace. Early on that got me thinking about cycles of violence in a global and historical sense. My conclusion is that we today have absolutely no sense of how bad things were for our ancestors.

As bad as WW1 and WW2 were, as bad as the Genocide was, the Taiping Rebellion, etc, they pale in comparison to the inhumanity of the past. Genocides of entire peoples have littered world history long before the industrial revolution, wholesale slaughter of entire populations, purges of all the men in an area, enslavement of the women, wars aimed solely to destroy a culture, these are regular markers of the past. These are also things we in the modern age have long forgotten.

As humans were are blinded by our inability to see things from a broad perspective; the current wars, conflicts, famines, etc all engage our mind. We are also blind to the amazing degree to which we have developed codified rules, limitations on power, ethics and norms which have curtailed our excesses. We think nothing of these, and act as if they account for little. Yet in the broad sweep of history, our modern institutions are light-years away from anything in the past. In a way these are a product of evolution, a manifestation of our tendencies towards increasing order when the conditions are right.

In a way we are spoiled, and tend to believe what we see today is more important than anything in the past, more risque, more dangerous, more brutal, etc. We fall prey to looking back on the past as some sort of halcyon era, a "better time," a mistake made by many posters here.

I agree with Jason that the call center jobs, although seemingly mundane and possibly misusing the Indian intellect, are indeed required since they, like any other profession, do support the Indian economy and the population. Although, I agree with "no no"'s one particular statement regarding the "[Indian's] genuine lack of interest in providing real and meaningful help". From customer service experience while talking to representatives both in India and the US, I have indeed experienced hostility and condescension among the former. I, however, don't have a point of reference for Philippines. If India wants to maintain its call center economy, as Jason points out, it has to welcome the competition and "improve its offerings".
